data.author: OAPK20
data.content: In related regulatory news, the London Stock Exchange and FCA have been concerned with misleading bulletin board commentary and potential market abuse. The FCA stresses that false or misleading statements online can breach Market Abuse Regulation (MAR) — positive or negative. That context matters: If a poster uses general regulatory changes to imply specific insider knowledge, that could itself be viewed as misleading commentary under MAR. The inference that this FCA bulletin is a near-term catalyst for share price movement in AMG is not supported directly by the bulletin itself. AMG — as an AIM-listed company — will eventually operate under the new admissions/prospectus regime once POATRs takes effect 19 January 2026. But it is not a catalyst specific to AMG. It’s a general rule change for the market at large. PMB 58 does not announce: Specific regulatory approval for AMG operations or permits A timetable for any decision affecting AMG Inside information about upcoming FCA action on AMG. So there is no direct regulatory inflection point for AMG spelled out in PMB 58. The inference that this FCA bulletin is a near-term catalyst for share price movement in AMG is not supported directly by the bulletin itself. PMB 58 is procedural and structural, not company-specific. It doesn’t contain approved news about AMG or any impending regulatory event. It’s a framework shift affecting most UK listed issuers, not a targeted development. If AMG intends to raise money or issue new securities, the new rules might eventually be beneficial — but not as an immediate trigger. What PMB 58 does NOT mean for AMG-  It does not announce regulatory approval. It does not provide inside information. It is not a company-specific catalyst. Posters may be trying to imply that regulatory reform broadly makes raising capital easier and that this could increase speculative interest or confidence. But assigning that as a short-term share price catalyst for AMG is not supported by the document itself.

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: Be wary of classic bulletin-board shorthand aimed at traders, not fundamentals investors. Those who constantly seeking to reassure holders that recent selling is “smart” or “managed”, not distressed. Those who constantly frame price action as constructive accumulation, not distribution. Trying to anchor expectations to a near-term catalyst (“next week”). This is soft ramping, not blatant hype. The motivation is to frame current trading as bullish smart-money positioning ahead of a catalyst, thereby supporting sentiment and near-term price expectations. It’s not evidence, but it is a useful tell about how the stock is being talked up into the next trading window. There is deliberate phrasing to justify Short-term volatility, Broker stock movement, Holding through uncertainty. This is doing a lot of work psychologically, but crucially, no details are provided, which allows readers to fill in the blanks with optimism. That strongly suggests a trader already positioned, or looking to exit into strength, or trying to stabilise sentiment before a catalyst (real or hoped-for). The repeated broker / volume behaviour claim without - Rising volume without VWAP drifting down - Late-day strength (not fades) - Sellers disappearing on dips - No spike in free float via RNS - would suggest recycling. If instead you see - Volume spikes + price capping - PEEL persistently on the offer - Close-at-low prints - then it’s distribution, not recycling. Does the predicted “regulatory inflection point” outcome change project economics? Or does it just allow the story to continue? If the latter expect recycling again. Why “regulatory inflection” is BB gold. It sounds binary and asymmetric, excuses volatility, can’t easily be disproven short-term, and creates a time anchor (“next week”) This is speculation-driven, not information-driven phrasing. Be wary of position-protective posting, not malicious, but not neutral. Typical motivations are prevent weak hands selling into their exit, encourage “one more week” holding behaviour, and frame noise as opportunity. Which is classic pre-event BB psychology. Such comments appear plausible, but not provable. It is sentiment management, not insight.

data.title: Update on Kyrgyz Uranium Asset
data.full_content:
Today 07:00
RNS Number : 1437S
Atlas Metals Group PLC
09 February 2026
9 February 2026
Atlas Metals Group plc
("
Atlas Metals
" or the "
Company
")
Update on
Kyrgyz
Uranium Asset
Atlas Metals (LSE: AMG), the natural resources and energy company, is pleased to provide an update on the Company's interest in the Kamushanovskoye uranium deposit, located in northern Kyrgyzstan, 48km northeast of the capital of the Kyrgyz Republic, Bishkek (the "
Project
"). The Project is owned by International Mining Company Invest Inc. ("
IMC
"), a US based company, and currently Atlas Metals has a 10 % interest in IMC.
Whilst the Company's primary focus remains on the proposed
acquisition of Universal Pozzolanic Silica Alumina Ltd ("
UPSA
") (the "
Proposed Acquisition
"), which is progressing well,
this update is provided in view of the significant increase in the uranium price since the Company invested in the Project in 2018. At that time, the in-situ value of contained uranium totalled US$151 million at a uranium price of US$27-28/lb. Over the last six months, the uranium price has reached US$80-85/lb, placing a value of approximately US$700 million on the contained resources.
The Project has been under exploration since 2011 and the State Reserve Committee of Kyrgyzstan ("
GKZ
") granted an application for a mining licence in January 2019 (the "
Mining Licence
") for 3,371.1 tonnes of uranium reserves (8.731 million lbs U3O8). This provides an in-situ value of approximately US$700 million at a uranium price of US$80-85/lb. In May 2019, the Kyrgyz parliament voted to ban uranium mining in the country and the Mining Licence was cancelled without any compensation. IMC contested this action and appealed the decision under international arbitration. Hearings were held in 2024-25 and a decision is in process (case ICSID ARB/22/25). The Company believes IMC's case is strengthened by the Parliament of Kyrgyzstan approving a bill lifting the ban on prospecting, exploration, development and mining of uranium and thorium in the Kyrgyz Republic in June 2024.
As part of the work completed since the grant of the Mining Licence and to support IMC's case at arbitration, a detailed review and assessment of the Project took place and was completed in 2024. The review was completed by Dr Mike Armitage, BSc, MIMMM, FGS, CEng, CGeol and confirmed both the potential viability of the extraction method as well as the resource estimate approved by GKZ.
The deposit is uranium oxide hosted in peat soils at depths from surface down to a maximum of 14 metres. Testwork on site of in-situ recovery (ISR) confirmed good extraction of uranium using sodium carbonate as the leaching solution. ISR comprises the injection of the leaching solution into the site and recovering the pregnant solution using shallow pump wells. The pregnant solution can be enhanced on site to a product than can be shipped for final processing. Due to the shallow depths and simple technology, the operating and capital costs are low.
Discussions are underway with possible development partners and the Kyrgyz government to find a satisfactory conclusion for all parties.
Chris Chadwick, Chief Executive Officer of Atlas Metals, commented:
"While our primary focus is on completing the transformative acquisition of UPSA, it is noteworthy that our long-term belief in Atlas'
Kyrgyz uranium

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: 3 May 2019 Farm-in Agreement update on Uranium Project MetalNRG plc (NEX:MNRG) today announces that it has suspended the terms of the farm-in agreement with IMC (the "Farm-in Agreement"), announced on 27 March 2019 (the "March Announcement") in relation to the Kamushanovskoye uranium deposit in Kyrgyzstan with a side letter dated 3 May 2019 (the "Side Letter"). Under the Side Letter, MetalNRG and IMC agree that: * IMC will waive the obligation of MetalNRG under the Farm-In Agreement to transfer to IMC the Initial Payment of $400,000, payable upon MetalNRG's proposed Admission to the Official List. * From the date hereof, and throughout the duration of the Uranium Ban, IMC will waive the obligation of MetalNRG under the Farm-In Agreement to make the Tranche Payments on each of the Agreed Dates. * From the date hereof, and throughout the duration of the Uranium Ban, the Right of First Refusal (as defined in the Farm-In Agreement) shall continue to apply in favour of MetalNRG. * If the Uranium Ban continues for a period of 12 months from the date hereof, MetalNRG shall have the right to terminate the Farm-In Agreement in its entirety by written notice to IMC and MetalNRG shall not be liable for any unpaid payments thereunder. * If, within 12 months of the date hereof, either (i) the Uranium Ban ceases to be in force or (ii) the government of the Kyrgyz Republic allows IMC to progress work under its existing mining license for the sole purpose of processing waste (an exemption under the Uranium Ban), MetalNRG may, in its sole discretion, elect to re-enter the Farm-In Agreement, subject to the adjustment, if necessary, of the Agreed Dates in relation to the Tranche Payments and valuation of the Uranium Project. IMC has continually held  that its activities at the Uranium Project of  'cleaning' the peat and contained groundwater, which carries high levels of uranium (such uranium often contaminating the local water supplies), amount to those of processing waste. IMC holds a mining licence with concomitant rights. The license was officially granted by the government of Kyrgyzstan in April 2019. MetalNRG's current economic interest in the Uranium Project, as a result of its total investment to date of US$170,650, is 8.5%

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: 6th Feb 2023 At the time of the ban, MetalNRG held a 9.9% equity interest in the asset; since the ban, MetalNRG has supported IMC with a convertible loan facility for a total of US$ 341,441 to date. The agreement between IMC and MetalNRG provides that  repayment of the convertible loan facility is either (i) via a conversion at 3 times the principal amount advanced into equity in IMC, if the project is reinstated; or (ii) repayment of 300% of the principal amount advanced in cash, in the event that IMC receives or reaches a compensatory settlement with the government of Kyrgyzstan. Following many months of negotiations with the incumbent Government, IMC has now filed for arbitration with the International Centre for Settlements of Investment disputes (the "ICSID"). IMC's claim before the ICSID is for a minimum compensatory payment of US$ 63 million, plus interest and legal fees, to be assessed. The ICSID tribunal designated to hear the claims has now been constituted and the first hearing is scheduled for  9 March 2023. The legal firm representing IMC, ENYO Law, who are based in London, have agreed a contingent fee arrangement based on the successful outcome of the claims presented to the ICSID. ENYO Law will receive 50% of any sums awarded, after the deduction of legal expenses. The balance of any award will be due to IMC (which will then distribute any sum on the basis of the arrangements currently in place with MetalNRG. If the case is lost before the ICSID, IMC has no obligations or liability for legal Enyo Law's fees.

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: The Kamushanovskoye uranium project itself is owned 100% by International Mining Company Invest Inc (IMC). Atlas Metals doesn’t own the asset. What AMG owns is a minority equity interest in IMC — usually described as 9.9%, sometimes rounded to 10%. Either way, it’s a non-controlling stake. So the obvious question is: how does AMG actually turn that into money? There aren’t many routes. The most straightforward would be selling the IMC shares. That only works if IMC equity is saleable, which probably means some combination of arbitration clarity, a settled licence position, or a partner deal that puts a real valuation on the project. Without one of those, there’s no obvious buyer. If the arbitration or licensing situation improves, AMG might be able to reverse some or all of the historic impairment. That would lift book value, but it’s accounting only — no cash comes in, and shareholders aren’t any better funded as a result. If IMC wins or settles the arbitration, any payout goes to IMC, not AMG. AMG only benefits if IMC decides to distribute cash, which is unlikely while the project still needs development capital. Even then, timing and amounts are completely unknown. Another possibility is a JV or farm-in at IMC level. A partner could fund development in return for an interest, which might re-rate IMC and, by extension, AMG’s stake. Again, that only matters if AMG then sells — there’s no automatic cash outcome. The important thing to keep in mind is that the US$700m “in-situ value” being quoted isn’t a valuation of IMC and certainly not a valuation of AMG’s interest. Any value to AMG here is indirect, minority, and conditional. In reality, this is optionality rather than monetisation — not that different from owning shares in AMG itself and hoping future events move the price.

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: Mr William Clifton (just why hasn’t he listed this on ASX?) owns Claystone Masonry and Claystone International and is a director of UPSA, how were the extraction rights and royalty terms benchmarked to ensure they are arm’s-length? What protections exist for UPSA shareholders if Claystone entities controlled by a UPSA director seek to renegotiate terms post-Admission? “ Under the 20 June 2023 Agreement, the parties agreed that the Lessee shall pay the Lessor the sum of US $3.00 per metric ton out of the consideration received by the Lessee from its sale or assignment of the deposit rights.” What does the owner of lots 5 and 6 get? TBC. “ a Deed of Agreement with the former Yallaroi Shire Council (now Gwydir Shire Council) was entered into. This required the upgrade of the road on a basis to be negotiated and payment of a contribution of $1.00 per tonne per load carried from the land until such time as the road is upgraded to a 2 lane gravel road with bitumen surface to an area adjacent to the house in the village of Kooloona. ” Has the road been built ? There is no mention in available council minutes from 2024–2025 of: • An Adams Scrub Road / Kooloona Road upgrade project • A completed bitumen upgrade between the quarry and Kooloona • A new sealed haulage route matching the 1980s consent requirement Eats into that £10. Makes the £5 question relevance clearer. On the information available, the $1 per tonne trucked still applies. Until the road is built. At scale: • 1 Mtpa = $1 million per year • 5 Mtpa = $5 million per year That is: • A real, recurring cash leakage • Not a one-off capex • Directly impacts EBITDA and valuation If anyone can, please confirm whether the $1.00 per tonne road contribution deed remains in force following the December 2016 modification, and if not, provide the executed deed of variation or council resolution extinguishing the obligation.

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: Please explain precisely who owns the PSA reserves, who owns the extraction rights, and under what circumstances those rights can be terminated, diluted, or renegotiated following a change of control. The RNS says UPSA has rights via an “extraction partner” and Claystone holds the original rights; detailed legal terms (termination, change-of-control provisions) are not yet disclosed. Most SCMs trade at £3–7/t in-ground, not £10. Who legally owns the carbon credits: UPSA or the concrete producer, and on which registry are they verified? If UPSA doesn’t own them, they don’t belong in the valuation. If the PSA were worth £5 per tonne and carbon credits were unavailable, would this transaction still proceed on the same terms?

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: A few points to separate structure from interpretation: • ATM facility = up to £10m over a minimum 1-year term • Initial 720,820 shares (2.99%) already issued to Axis at par and will be sold into the market • Warrants exercised: 631,578 shares @ 10p (~£63k cash) • CLNs converted: £387,550 @ 10.52p = 3,664,923 shares • Total new shares in this RNS: 5,017,321 • Total shares post-Admission: 29,124,930 An ATM is a capital supply mechanism, not a timing signal. It exists to be used when liquidity allows, not “after” a value event by design. While management states an objective of minimising dilution, the capacity itself introduces ongoing supply and price-dependent funding risk. Intent does not remove structure. If fully drawn at ~10p, £10m implies ~100m additional shares. That possibility is embedded regardless of whether or when it is used. This RNS improves runway and reduces near-term funding pressure. It does not change UPSA RTO economics, de-risk completion, or alter the contractual ~3% post-RTO position for legacy holders. ATM facilities are typically used when optionality exists but certainty has not yet been earned.

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: The RNS shows an ATM facility + warrant/loan conversion, which is standard bridge financing when optionality is high but certainty is still low. It supports working capital and RTO costs, but it is not growth capital and does not validate valuation. ATM facilities improve short-term solvency, not long-term equity value, and introduce ongoing supply by design. That’s normal ahead of a high-uncertainty event like an RTO. Upside still depends on the prospectus, funding terms and asset de-risking. This RNS doesn’t change those economics — it just extends the runway.

data.content: The ATM isn’t a value-timed bet — it’s liquidity financing. If fully drawn at ~10p, it adds ~100m shares, taking the pre-RTO count to ~129m (≈77% dilution). data.author: OAPK20
data.content: The RNS shows an ATM facility + warrant/loan conversion, which is standard bridge financing when optionality is high but certainty is still low. It supports working capital and RTO costs, but it is not growth capital and does not validate valuation. ATM facilities improve short-term solvency, not long-term equity value, and introduce ongoing supply by design. That’s normal ahead of a high-uncertainty event like an RTO. Upside still depends on the prospectus, funding terms and asset de-risking. This RNS doesn’t change those economics — it just extends the runway.

data.author: SmoothOperater
data.content: PEEL is the broker, book runner,  liquidity provider,  and market maker. There's an RTO event coming. Whilst PEEL is carrying their duties in the above roles, their holdings are changeable,  therefore they have released an RNS as below  10% range. The next reportable range is 5%, so PEEL are holding  between  5% to 9.9%. They are using ranges to prevent multiple RNS daily. If PEEL were looking to exit , they would not position themselves as prime buyer currently. If you were to sell shares right now it would be PEEL  taking them, if you were to buy shares right now it would be a different market maker giving them.

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: Amadan filling the vacuum with speculation to stay relevant on the BB. Is there much to read into the director appointment on its own? Yes, directors can be appointed ahead of strategic events, but AMG already has a clearly signposted one in progress — the proposed UPSA acquisition, drilling programme and CPR upgrade have all been explicitly flagged in RNS, with timelines into early 2026. You don’t really need to infer anything extra from a routine board change when the company itself has already laid out the roadmap. On the “director for hire” point, having multiple appointments is pretty common on AIM, particularly for NEDs brought in for governance, compliance or transaction experience. Unless there’s disclosure of equity incentives, warrants or deal-linked remuneration (which would normally require an RNS), it’s hard to conclude much beyond standard housekeeping. If anything, adding another director while progressing a potentially transformational acquisition is fairly normal — especially with a CPR, off-take discussions and possible re-admission considerations ahead. The material questions remain the same as before: •	quality of the upgraded CPR (measured vs inferred), •	conversion of LOIs into binding off-take, •	and the final structure/dilution of the UPSA transaction. The director appointment feels like background noise compared to those.

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: In related regulatory news, the London Stock Exchange and FCA have been concerned with misleading bulletin board commentary and potential market abuse. The FCA stresses that false or misleading statements online can breach Market Abuse Regulation (MAR) — positive or negative. That context matters: If a poster uses general regulatory changes to imply specific insider knowledge, that could itself be viewed as misleading commentary under MAR. The inference that this FCA bulletin is a near-term catalyst for share price movement in AMG is not supported directly by the bulletin itself. AMG — as an AIM-listed company — will eventually operate under the new admissions/prospectus regime once POATRs takes effect 19 January 2026. But it is not a catalyst specific to AMG. It’s a general rule change for the market at large. PMB 58 does not announce: Specific regulatory approval for AMG operations or permits A timetable for any decision affecting AMG Inside information about upcoming FCA action on AMG. So there is no direct regulatory inflection point for AMG spelled out in PMB 58. The inference that this FCA bulletin is a near-term catalyst for share price movement in AMG is not supported directly by the bulletin itself. PMB 58 is procedural and structural, not company-specific. It doesn’t contain approved news about AMG or any impending regulatory event. It’s a framework shift affecting most UK listed issuers, not a targeted development. If AMG intends to raise money or issue new securities, the new rules might eventually be beneficial — but not as an immediate trigger. What PMB 58 does NOT mean for AMG-  It does not announce regulatory approval. It does not provide inside information. It is not a company-specific catalyst. Posters may be trying to imply that regulatory reform broadly makes raising capital easier and that this could increase speculative interest or confidence. But assigning that as a short-term share price catalyst for AMG is not supported by the document itself.

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: Be wary of classic bulletin-board shorthand aimed at traders, not fundamentals investors. Those who constantly seeking to reassure holders that recent selling is “smart” or “managed”, not distressed. Those who constantly frame price action as constructive accumulation, not distribution. Trying to anchor expectations to a near-term catalyst (“next week”). This is soft ramping, not blatant hype. The motivation is to frame current trading as bullish smart-money positioning ahead of a catalyst, thereby supporting sentiment and near-term price expectations. It’s not evidence, but it is a useful tell about how the stock is being talked up into the next trading window. There is deliberate phrasing to justify Short-term volatility, Broker stock movement, Holding through uncertainty. This is doing a lot of work psychologically, but crucially, no details are provided, which allows readers to fill in the blanks with optimism. That strongly suggests a trader already positioned, or looking to exit into strength, or trying to stabilise sentiment before a catalyst (real or hoped-for). The repeated broker / volume behaviour claim without - Rising volume without VWAP drifting down - Late-day strength (not fades) - Sellers disappearing on dips - No spike in free float via RNS - would suggest recycling. If instead you see - Volume spikes + price capping - PEEL persistently on the offer - Close-at-low prints - then it’s distribution, not recycling. Does the predicted “regulatory inflection point” outcome change project economics? Or does it just allow the story to continue? If the latter expect recycling again. Why “regulatory inflection” is BB gold. It sounds binary and asymmetric, excuses volatility, can’t easily be disproven short-term, and creates a time anchor (“next week”) This is speculation-driven, not information-driven phrasing. Be wary of position-protective posting, not malicious, but not neutral. Typical motivations are prevent weak hands selling into their exit, encourage “one more week” holding behaviour, and frame noise as opportunity. Which is classic pre-event BB psychology. Such comments appear plausible, but not provable. It is sentiment management, not insight.

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: 3 May 2019 Farm-in Agreement update on Uranium Project MetalNRG plc (NEX:MNRG) today announces that it has suspended the terms of the farm-in agreement with IMC (the "Farm-in Agreement"), announced on 27 March 2019 (the "March Announcement") in relation to the Kamushanovskoye uranium deposit in Kyrgyzstan with a side letter dated 3 May 2019 (the "Side Letter"). Under the Side Letter, MetalNRG and IMC agree that: * IMC will waive the obligation of MetalNRG under the Farm-In Agreement to transfer to IMC the Initial Payment of $400,000, payable upon MetalNRG's proposed Admission to the Official List. * From the date hereof, and throughout the duration of the Uranium Ban, IMC will waive the obligation of MetalNRG under the Farm-In Agreement to make the Tranche Payments on each of the Agreed Dates. * From the date hereof, and throughout the duration of the Uranium Ban, the Right of First Refusal (as defined in the Farm-In Agreement) shall continue to apply in favour of MetalNRG. * If the Uranium Ban continues for a period of 12 months from the date hereof, MetalNRG shall have the right to terminate the Farm-In Agreement in its entirety by written notice to IMC and MetalNRG shall not be liable for any unpaid payments thereunder. * If, within 12 months of the date hereof, either (i) the Uranium Ban ceases to be in force or (ii) the government of the Kyrgyz Republic allows IMC to progress work under its existing mining license for the sole purpose of processing waste (an exemption under the Uranium Ban), MetalNRG may, in its sole discretion, elect to re-enter the Farm-In Agreement, subject to the adjustment, if necessary, of the Agreed Dates in relation to the Tranche Payments and valuation of the Uranium Project. IMC has continually held  that its activities at the Uranium Project of  'cleaning' the peat and contained groundwater, which carries high levels of uranium (such uranium often contaminating the local water supplies), amount to those of processing waste. IMC holds a mining licence with concomitant rights. The license was officially granted by the government of Kyrgyzstan in April 2019. MetalNRG's current economic interest in the Uranium Project, as a result of its total investment to date of US$170,650, is 8.5%

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: 6th Feb 2023 At the time of the ban, MetalNRG held a 9.9% equity interest in the asset; since the ban, MetalNRG has supported IMC with a convertible loan facility for a total of US$ 341,441 to date. The agreement between IMC and MetalNRG provides that  repayment of the convertible loan facility is either (i) via a conversion at 3 times the principal amount advanced into equity in IMC, if the project is reinstated; or (ii) repayment of 300% of the principal amount advanced in cash, in the event that IMC receives or reaches a compensatory settlement with the government of Kyrgyzstan. Following many months of negotiations with the incumbent Government, IMC has now filed for arbitration with the International Centre for Settlements of Investment disputes (the "ICSID"). IMC's claim before the ICSID is for a minimum compensatory payment of US$ 63 million, plus interest and legal fees, to be assessed. The ICSID tribunal designated to hear the claims has now been constituted and the first hearing is scheduled for  9 March 2023. The legal firm representing IMC, ENYO Law, who are based in London, have agreed a contingent fee arrangement based on the successful outcome of the claims presented to the ICSID. ENYO Law will receive 50% of any sums awarded, after the deduction of legal expenses. The balance of any award will be due to IMC (which will then distribute any sum on the basis of the arrangements currently in place with MetalNRG. If the case is lost before the ICSID, IMC has no obligations or liability for legal Enyo Law's fees.

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: The Kamushanovskoye uranium project itself is owned 100% by International Mining Company Invest Inc (IMC). Atlas Metals doesn’t own the asset. What AMG owns is a minority equity interest in IMC — usually described as 9.9%, sometimes rounded to 10%. Either way, it’s a non-controlling stake. So the obvious question is: how does AMG actually turn that into money? There aren’t many routes. The most straightforward would be selling the IMC shares. That only works if IMC equity is saleable, which probably means some combination of arbitration clarity, a settled licence position, or a partner deal that puts a real valuation on the project. Without one of those, there’s no obvious buyer. If the arbitration or licensing situation improves, AMG might be able to reverse some or all of the historic impairment. That would lift book value, but it’s accounting only — no cash comes in, and shareholders aren’t any better funded as a result. If IMC wins or settles the arbitration, any payout goes to IMC, not AMG. AMG only benefits if IMC decides to distribute cash, which is unlikely while the project still needs development capital. Even then, timing and amounts are completely unknown. Another possibility is a JV or farm-in at IMC level. A partner could fund development in return for an interest, which might re-rate IMC and, by extension, AMG’s stake. Again, that only matters if AMG then sells — there’s no automatic cash outcome. The important thing to keep in mind is that the US$700m “in-situ value” being quoted isn’t a valuation of IMC and certainly not a valuation of AMG’s interest. Any value to AMG here is indirect, minority, and conditional. In reality, this is optionality rather than monetisation — not that different from owning shares in AMG itself and hoping future events move the price.

data.content: 6th Feb 2023 At the time of the ban, MetalNRG held a 9.9% equity interest in the asset; since the ban, MetalNRG has supported IMC with a convertible loan facility for a total of US$ 341,441 to date. The agreement between IMC and MetalNRG provides that  repayment of the convertible loan facility is either (i) via a conversion at 3 times the principal amount advanced into equity in IMC, if the project is reinstated; or (ii) repayment of 300% of the principal amount advanced in cash, in the event that IMC receives or reaches a compensatory settlement with the government of Kyrgyzstan. Following many months of negotiations with the incumbent Government, IMC has now filed for arbitration with the International Centre for Settlements of Investment disputes (the "ICSID"). IMC's claim before the ICSID is for a minimum compensatory payment of US$ 63 million, plus interest and legal fees, to be assessed. The ICSID tribunal designated to hear the claims has now been constituted and the first hearing is scheduled for  9 March 2023. The legal firm representing IMC, ENYO Law, who are based in London, have agreed a contingent fee arrangement based on the successful outcome of the claims presented to the ICSID. ENYO Law will receive 50% of any sums awarded, after the deduction of legal expenses. The balance of any award will be due to IMC (which will then distribute any sum on the basis of the arrangements currently in place with MetalNRG. If the case is lost before the ICSID, IMC has no obligations or liability for legal Enyo Law's fees.

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: The Kamushanovskoye uranium project itself is owned 100% by International Mining Company Invest Inc (IMC). Atlas Metals doesn’t own the asset. What AMG owns is a minority equity interest in IMC — usually described as 9.9%, sometimes rounded to 10%. Either way, it’s a non-controlling stake. So the obvious question is: how does AMG actually turn that into money? There aren’t many routes. The most straightforward would be selling the IMC shares. That only works if IMC equity is saleable, which probably means some combination of arbitration clarity, a settled licence position, or a partner deal that puts a real valuation on the project. Without one of those, there’s no obvious buyer. If the arbitration or licensing situation improves, AMG might be able to reverse some or all of the historic impairment. That would lift book value, but it’s accounting only — no cash comes in, and shareholders aren’t any better funded as a result. If IMC wins or settles the arbitration, any payout goes to IMC, not AMG. AMG only benefits if IMC decides to distribute cash, which is unlikely while the project still needs development capital. Even then, timing and amounts are completely unknown. Another possibility is a JV or farm-in at IMC level. A partner could fund development in return for an interest, which might re-rate IMC and, by extension, AMG’s stake. Again, that only matters if AMG then sells — there’s no automatic cash outcome. The important thing to keep in mind is that the US$700m “in-situ value” being quoted isn’t a valuation of IMC and certainly not a valuation of AMG’s interest. Any value to AMG here is indirect, minority, and conditional. In reality, this is optionality rather than monetisation — not that different from owning shares in AMG itself and hoping future events move the price.

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: Mr William Clifton (just why hasn’t he listed this on ASX?) owns Claystone Masonry and Claystone International and is a director of UPSA, how were the extraction rights and royalty terms benchmarked to ensure they are arm’s-length? What protections exist for UPSA shareholders if Claystone entities controlled by a UPSA director seek to renegotiate terms post-Admission? “ Under the 20 June 2023 Agreement, the parties agreed that the Lessee shall pay the Lessor the sum of US $3.00 per metric ton out of the consideration received by the Lessee from its sale or assignment of the deposit rights.” What does the owner of lots 5 and 6 get? TBC. “ a Deed of Agreement with the former Yallaroi Shire Council (now Gwydir Shire Council) was entered into. This required the upgrade of the road on a basis to be negotiated and payment of a contribution of $1.00 per tonne per load carried from the land until such time as the road is upgraded to a 2 lane gravel road with bitumen surface to an area adjacent to the house in the village of Kooloona. ” Has the road been built ? There is no mention in available council minutes from 2024–2025 of: • An Adams Scrub Road / Kooloona Road upgrade project • A completed bitumen upgrade between the quarry and Kooloona • A new sealed haulage route matching the 1980s consent requirement Eats into that £10. Makes the £5 question relevance clearer. On the information available, the $1 per tonne trucked still applies. Until the road is built. At scale: • 1 Mtpa = $1 million per year • 5 Mtpa = $5 million per year That is: • A real, recurring cash leakage • Not a one-off capex • Directly impacts EBITDA and valuation If anyone can, please confirm whether the $1.00 per tonne road contribution deed remains in force following the December 2016 modification, and if not, provide the executed deed of variation or council resolution extinguishing the obligation.

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: Please explain precisely who owns the PSA reserves, who owns the extraction rights, and under what circumstances those rights can be terminated, diluted, or renegotiated following a change of control. The RNS says UPSA has rights via an “extraction partner” and Claystone holds the original rights; detailed legal terms (termination, change-of-control provisions) are not yet disclosed. Most SCMs trade at £3–7/t in-ground, not £10. Who legally owns the carbon credits: UPSA or the concrete producer, and on which registry are they verified? If UPSA doesn’t own them, they don’t belong in the valuation. If the PSA were worth £5 per tonne and carbon credits were unavailable, would this transaction still proceed on the same terms?

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: A few points to separate structure from interpretation: • ATM facility = up to £10m over a minimum 1-year term • Initial 720,820 shares (2.99%) already issued to Axis at par and will be sold into the market • Warrants exercised: 631,578 shares @ 10p (~£63k cash) • CLNs converted: £387,550 @ 10.52p = 3,664,923 shares • Total new shares in this RNS: 5,017,321 • Total shares post-Admission: 29,124,930 An ATM is a capital supply mechanism, not a timing signal. It exists to be used when liquidity allows, not “after” a value event by design. While management states an objective of minimising dilution, the capacity itself introduces ongoing supply and price-dependent funding risk. Intent does not remove structure. If fully drawn at ~10p, £10m implies ~100m additional shares. That possibility is embedded regardless of whether or when it is used. This RNS improves runway and reduces near-term funding pressure. It does not change UPSA RTO economics, de-risk completion, or alter the contractual ~3% post-RTO position for legacy holders. ATM facilities are typically used when optionality exists but certainty has not yet been earned.

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: A few points to separate structure from interpretation: • ATM facility = up to £10m over a minimum 1-year term • Initial 720,820 shares (2.99%) already issued to Axis at par and will be sold into the market • Warrants exercised: 631,578 shares @ 10p (~£63k cash) • CLNs converted: £387,550 @ 10.52p = 3,664,923 shares • Total new shares in this RNS: 5,017,321 • Total shares post-Admission: 29,124,930 An ATM is a capital supply mechanism, not a timing signal. It exists to be used when liquidity allows, not “after” a value event by design. While management states an objective of minimising dilution, the capacity itself introduces ongoing supply and price-dependent funding risk. Intent does not remove structure. If fully drawn at ~10p, £10m implies ~100m additional shares. That possibility is embedded regardless of whether or when it is used. This RNS improves runway and reduces near-term funding pressure. It does not change UPSA RTO economics, de-risk completion, or alter the contractual ~3% post-RTO position for legacy holders. ATM facilities are typically used when optionality exists but certainty has not yet been earned.

data.author: SmoothOperater
data.content: PEEL is the broker, book runner,  liquidity provider,  and market maker. There's an RTO event coming. Whilst PEEL is carrying their duties in the above roles, their holdings are changeable,  therefore they have released an RNS as below  10% range. The next reportable range is 5%, so PEEL are holding  between  5% to 9.9%. They are using ranges to prevent multiple RNS daily. If PEEL were looking to exit , they would not position themselves as prime buyer currently. data.author: OAPK20
data.content: Amadan filling the vacuum with speculation to stay relevant on the BB. Is there much to read into the director appointment on its own? Yes, directors can be appointed ahead of strategic events, but AMG already has a clearly signposted one in progress — the proposed UPSA acquisition, drilling programme and CPR upgrade have all been explicitly flagged in RNS, with timelines into early 2026. You don’t really need to infer anything extra from a routine board change when the company itself has already laid out the roadmap. On the “director for hire” point, having multiple appointments is pretty common on AIM, particularly for NEDs brought in for governance, compliance or transaction experience. Unless there’s disclosure of equity incentives, warrants or deal-linked remuneration (which would normally require an RNS), it’s hard to conclude much beyond standard housekeeping. If anything, adding another director while progressing a potentially transformational acquisition is fairly normal — especially with a CPR, off-take discussions and possible re-admission considerations ahead. The material questions remain the same as before: •	quality of the upgraded CPR (measured vs inferred), •	conversion of LOIs into binding off-take, •	and the final structure/dilution of the UPSA transaction. The director appointment feels like background noise compared to those.

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: In related regulatory news, the London Stock Exchange and FCA have been concerned with misleading bulletin board commentary and potential market abuse. The FCA stresses that false or misleading statements online can breach Market Abuse Regulation (MAR) — positive or negative. That context matters: If a poster uses general regulatory changes to imply specific insider knowledge, that could itself be viewed as misleading commentary under MAR. The inference that this FCA bulletin is a near-term catalyst for share price movement in AMG is not supported directly by the bulletin itself. AMG — as an AIM-listed company — will eventually operate under the new admissions/prospectus regime once POATRs takes effect 19 January 2026. But it is not a catalyst specific to AMG. It’s a general rule change for the market at large. PMB 58 does not announce: Specific regulatory approval for AMG operations or permits A timetable for any decision affecting AMG Inside information about upcoming FCA action on AMG. So there is no direct regulatory inflection point for AMG spelled out in PMB 58. The inference that this FCA bulletin is a near-term catalyst for share price movement in AMG is not supported directly by the bulletin itself. PMB 58 is procedural and structural, not company-specific. It doesn’t contain approved news about AMG or any impending regulatory event. It’s a framework shift affecting most UK listed issuers, not a targeted development. If AMG intends to raise money or issue new securities, the new rules might eventually be beneficial — but not as an immediate trigger. What PMB 58 does NOT mean for AMG-  It does not announce regulatory approval. It does not provide inside information. It is not a company-specific catalyst. Posters may be trying to imply that regulatory reform broadly makes raising capital easier and that this could increase speculative interest or confidence. But assigning that as a short-term share price catalyst for AMG is not supported by the document itself.
data.thread_title: RE: New FCA rules from Monday

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: Be wary of classic bulletin-board shorthand aimed at traders, not fundamentals investors. Those who constantly seeking to reassure holders that recent selling is “smart” or “managed”, not distressed. Those who constantly frame price action as constructive accumulation, not distribution. Trying to anchor expectations to a near-term catalyst (“next week”). This is soft ramping, not blatant hype. The motivation is to frame current trading as bullish smart-money positioning ahead of a catalyst, thereby supporting sentiment and near-term price expectations. It’s not evidence, but it is a useful tell about how the stock is being talked up into the next trading window. There is deliberate phrasing to justify Short-term volatility, Broker stock movement, Holding through uncertainty. This is doing a lot of work psychologically, but crucially, no details are provided, which allows readers to fill in the blanks with optimism. That strongly suggests a trader already positioned, or looking to exit into strength, or trying to stabilise sentiment before a catalyst (real or hoped-for). The repeated broker / volume behaviour claim without - Rising volume without VWAP drifting down - Late-day strength (not fades) - Sellers disappearing on dips - No spike in free float via RNS - would suggest recycling. If instead you see - Volume spikes + price capping - PEEL persistently on the offer - Close-at-low prints - then it’s distribution, not recycling. Does the predicted “regulatory inflection point” outcome change project economics? Or does it just allow the story to continue? If the latter expect recycling again. Why “regulatory inflection” is BB gold. It sounds binary and asymmetric, excuses volatility, can’t easily be disproven short-term, and creates a time anchor (“next week”) This is speculation-driven, not information-driven phrasing. Be wary of position-protective posting, not malicious, but not neutral. Typical motivations are prevent weak hands selling into their exit, encourage “one more week” holding behaviour, and frame noise as opportunity. Which is classic pre-event BB psychology. Such comments appear plausible, but not provable. It is sentiment management, not insight.

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: 3 May 2019 Farm-in Agreement update on Uranium Project MetalNRG plc (NEX:MNRG) today announces that it has suspended the terms of the farm-in agreement with IMC (the "Farm-in Agreement"), announced on 27 March 2019 (the "March Announcement") in relation to the Kamushanovskoye uranium deposit in Kyrgyzstan with a side letter dated 3 May 2019 (the "Side Letter"). Under the Side Letter, MetalNRG and IMC agree that: * IMC will waive the obligation of MetalNRG under the Farm-In Agreement to transfer to IMC the Initial Payment of $400,000, payable upon MetalNRG's proposed Admission to the Official List. * From the date hereof, and throughout the duration of the Uranium Ban, IMC will waive the obligation of MetalNRG under the Farm-In Agreement to make the Tranche Payments on each of the Agreed Dates. * From the date hereof, and throughout the duration of the Uranium Ban, the Right of First Refusal (as defined in the Farm-In Agreement) shall continue to apply in favour of MetalNRG. * If the Uranium Ban continues for a period of 12 months from the date hereof, MetalNRG shall have the right to terminate the Farm-In Agreement in its entirety by written notice to IMC and MetalNRG shall not be liable for any unpaid payments thereunder. * If, within 12 months of the date hereof, either (i) the Uranium Ban ceases to be in force or (ii) the government of the Kyrgyz Republic allows IMC to progress work under its existing mining license for the sole purpose of processing waste (an exemption under the Uranium Ban), MetalNRG may, in its sole discretion, elect to re-enter the Farm-In Agreement, subject to the adjustment, if necessary, of the Agreed Dates in relation to the Tranche Payments and valuation of the Uranium Project. IMC has continually held  that its activities at the Uranium Project of  'cleaning' the peat and contained groundwater, which carries high levels of uranium (such uranium often contaminating the local water supplies), amount to those of processing waste. IMC holds a mining licence with concomitant rights. The license was officially granted by the government of Kyrgyzstan in April 2019. MetalNRG's current economic interest in the Uranium Project, as a result of its total investment to date of US$170,650, is 8.5%

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: 6th Feb 2023 At the time of the ban, MetalNRG held a 9.9% equity interest in the asset; since the ban, MetalNRG has supported IMC with a convertible loan facility for a total of US$ 341,441 to date. The agreement between IMC and MetalNRG provides that  repayment of the convertible loan facility is either (i) via a conversion at 3 times the principal amount advanced into equity in IMC, if the project is reinstated; or (ii) repayment of 300% of the principal amount advanced in cash, in the event that IMC receives or reaches a compensatory settlement with the government of Kyrgyzstan. Following many months of negotiations with the incumbent Government, IMC has now filed for arbitration with the International Centre for Settlements of Investment disputes (the "ICSID"). IMC's claim before the ICSID is for a minimum compensatory payment of US$ 63 million, plus interest and legal fees, to be assessed. The ICSID tribunal designated to hear the claims has now been constituted and the first hearing is scheduled for  9 March 2023. The legal firm representing IMC, ENYO Law, who are based in London, have agreed a contingent fee arrangement based on the successful outcome of the claims presented to the ICSID. ENYO Law will receive 50% of any sums awarded, after the deduction of legal expenses. The balance of any award will be due to IMC (which will then distribute any sum on the basis of the arrangements currently in place with MetalNRG. If the case is lost before the ICSID, IMC has no obligations or liability for legal Enyo Law's fees.

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: The Kamushanovskoye uranium project itself is owned 100% by International Mining Company Invest Inc (IMC). Atlas Metals doesn’t own the asset. What AMG owns is a minority equity interest in IMC — usually described as 9.9%, sometimes rounded to 10%. Either way, it’s a non-controlling stake. So the obvious question is: how does AMG actually turn that into money? There aren’t many routes. The most straightforward would be selling the IMC shares. That only works if IMC equity is saleable, which probably means some combination of arbitration clarity, a settled licence position, or a partner deal that puts a real valuation on the project. Without one of those, there’s no obvious buyer. If the arbitration or licensing situation improves, AMG might be able to reverse some or all of the historic impairment. That would lift book value, but it’s accounting only — no cash comes in, and shareholders aren’t any better funded as a result. If IMC wins or settles the arbitration, any payout goes to IMC, not AMG. AMG only benefits if IMC decides to distribute cash, which is unlikely while the project still needs development capital. Even then, timing and amounts are completely unknown. Another possibility is a JV or farm-in at IMC level. A partner could fund development in return for an interest, which might re-rate IMC and, by extension, AMG’s stake. Again, that only matters if AMG then sells — there’s no automatic cash outcome. The important thing to keep in mind is that the US$700m “in-situ value” being quoted isn’t a valuation of IMC and certainly not a valuation of AMG’s interest. Any value to AMG here is indirect, minority, and conditional. In reality, this is optionality rather than monetisation — not that different from owning shares in AMG itself and hoping future events move the price.

Under the Side Letter, MetalNRG and IMC agree that: * IMC will waive the obligation of MetalNRG under the Farm-In Agreement to transfer to IMC the Initial Payment of $400,000, payable upon MetalNRG's proposed Admission to the Official List. * From the date hereof, and throughout the duration of the Uranium Ban, IMC will waive the obligation of MetalNRG under the Farm-In Agreement to make the Tranche Payments on each of the Agreed Dates. * From the date hereof, and throughout the duration of the Uranium Ban, the Right of First Refusal (as defined in the Farm-In Agreement) shall continue to apply in favour of MetalNRG. * If the Uranium Ban continues for a period of 12 months from the date hereof, MetalNRG shall have the right to terminate the Farm-In Agreement in its entirety by written notice to IMC and MetalNRG shall not be liable for any unpaid payments thereunder. * If, within 12 months of the date hereof, either (i) the Uranium Ban ceases to be in force or (ii) the government of the Kyrgyz Republic allows IMC to progress work under its existing mining license for the sole purpose of processing waste (an exemption under the Uranium Ban), MetalNRG may, in its sole discretion, elect to re-enter the Farm-In Agreement, subject to the adjustment, if necessary, of the Agreed Dates in relation to the Tranche Payments and valuation of the Uranium Project. IMC has continually held  that its activities at the Uranium Project of  'cleaning' the peat and contained groundwater, which carries high levels of uranium (such uranium often contaminating the local water supplies), amount to those of processing waste. IMC holds a mining licence with concomitant rights. The license was officially granted by the government of Kyrgyzstan in April 2019. MetalNRG's current economic interest in the Uranium Project, as a result of its total investment to date of US$170,650, is 8.5%

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: 6th Feb 2023 At the time of the ban, MetalNRG held a 9.9% equity interest in the asset; since the ban, MetalNRG has supported IMC with a convertible loan facility for a total of US$ 341,441 to date. The agreement between IMC and MetalNRG provides that  repayment of the convertible loan facility is either (i) via a conversion at 3 times the principal amount advanced into equity in IMC, if the project is reinstated; or (ii) repayment of 300% of the principal amount advanced in cash, in the event that IMC receives or reaches a compensatory settlement with the government of Kyrgyzstan. Following many months of negotiations with the incumbent Government, IMC has now filed for arbitration with the International Centre for Settlements of Investment disputes (the "ICSID"). IMC's claim before the ICSID is for a minimum compensatory payment of US$ 63 million, plus interest and legal fees, to be assessed. The ICSID tribunal designated to hear the claims has now been constituted and the first hearing is scheduled for  9 March 2023. The legal firm representing IMC, ENYO Law, who are based in London, have agreed a contingent fee arrangement based on the successful outcome of the claims presented to the ICSID. ENYO Law will receive 50% of any sums awarded, after the deduction of legal expenses. The balance of any award will be due to IMC (which will then distribute any sum on the basis of the arrangements currently in place with MetalNRG. If the case is lost before the ICSID, IMC has no obligations or liability for legal Enyo Law's fees.

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: The Kamushanovskoye uranium project itself is owned 100% by International Mining Company Invest Inc (IMC). Atlas Metals doesn’t own the asset. What AMG owns is a minority equity interest in IMC — usually described as 9.9%, sometimes rounded to 10%. Either way, it’s a non-controlling stake. So the obvious question is: how does AMG actually turn that into money? There aren’t many routes. The most straightforward would be selling the IMC shares. That only works if IMC equity is saleable, which probably means some combination of arbitration clarity, a settled licence position, or a partner deal that puts a real valuation on the project. Without one of those, there’s no obvious buyer. If the arbitration or licensing situation improves, AMG might be able to reverse some or all of the historic impairment. That would lift book value, but it’s accounting only — no cash comes in, and shareholders aren’t any better funded as a result. If IMC wins or settles the arbitration, any payout goes to IMC, not AMG. AMG only benefits if IMC decides to distribute cash, which is unlikely while the project still needs development capital. Even then, timing and amounts are completely unknown. Another possibility is a JV or farm-in at IMC level. A partner could fund development in return for an interest, which might re-rate IMC and, by extension, AMG’s stake. Again, that only matters if AMG then sells — there’s no automatic cash outcome. The important thing to keep in mind is that the US$700m “in-situ value” being quoted isn’t a valuation of IMC and certainly not a valuation of AMG’s interest. Any value to AMG here is indirect, minority, and conditional. In reality, this is optionality rather than monetisation — not that different from owning shares in AMG itself and hoping future events move the price.

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: Mr William Clifton (just why hasn’t he listed this on ASX?) owns Claystone Masonry and Claystone International and is a director of UPSA, how were the extraction rights and royalty terms benchmarked to ensure they are arm’s-length? What protections exist for UPSA shareholders if Claystone entities controlled by a UPSA director seek to renegotiate terms post-Admission? “ Under the 20 June 2023 Agreement, the parties agreed that the Lessee shall pay the Lessor the sum of US $3.00 per metric ton out of the consideration received by the Lessee from its sale or assignment of the deposit rights.” What does the owner of lots 5 and 6 get? TBC. “ a Deed of Agreement with the former Yallaroi Shire Council (now Gwydir Shire Council) was entered into. This required the upgrade of the road on a basis to be negotiated and payment of a contribution of $1.00 per tonne per load carried from the land until such time as the road is upgraded to a 2 lane gravel road with bitumen surface to an area adjacent to the house in the village of Kooloona. ” Has the road been built ? There is no mention in available council minutes from 2024–2025 of: • An Adams Scrub Road / Kooloona Road upgrade project • A completed bitumen upgrade between the quarry and Kooloona • A new sealed haulage route matching the 1980s consent requirement Eats into that £10. Makes the £5 question relevance clearer. On the information available, the $1 per tonne trucked still applies. Until the road is built. At scale: • 1 Mtpa = $1 million per year • 5 Mtpa = $5 million per year That is: • A real, recurring cash leakage • Not a one-off capex • Directly impacts EBITDA and valuation If anyone can, please confirm whether the $1.00 per tonne road contribution deed remains in force following the December 2016 modification, and if not, provide the executed deed of variation or council resolution extinguishing the obligation.

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: Please explain precisely who owns the PSA reserves, who owns the extraction rights, and under what circumstances those rights can be terminated, diluted, or renegotiated following a change of control. The RNS says UPSA has rights via an “extraction partner” and Claystone holds the original rights; detailed legal terms (termination, change-of-control provisions) are not yet disclosed. Most SCMs trade at £3–7/t in-ground, not £10. Who legally owns the carbon credits: UPSA or the concrete producer, and on which registry are they verified? If UPSA doesn’t own them, they don’t belong in the valuation. If the PSA were worth £5 per tonne and carbon credits were unavailable, would this transaction still proceed on the same terms?

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: A few points to separate structure from interpretation: • ATM facility = up to £10m over a minimum 1-year term • Initial 720,820 shares (2.99%) already issued to Axis at par and will be sold into the market • Warrants exercised: 631,578 shares @ 10p (~£63k cash) • CLNs converted: £387,550 @ 10.52p = 3,664,923 shares • Total new shares in this RNS: 5,017,321 • Total shares post-Admission: 29,124,930 An ATM is a capital supply mechanism, not a timing signal. It exists to be used when liquidity allows, not “after” a value event by design. While management states an objective of minimising dilution, the capacity itself introduces ongoing supply and price-dependent funding risk. Intent does not remove structure. If fully drawn at ~10p, £10m implies ~100m additional shares. That possibility is embedded regardless of whether or when it is used. This RNS improves runway and reduces near-term funding pressure. It does not change UPSA RTO economics, de-risk completion, or alter the contractual ~3% post-RTO position for legacy holders. ATM facilities are typically used when optionality exists but certainty has not yet been earned.

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: The RNS shows an ATM facility + warrant/loan conversion, which is standard bridge financing when optionality is high but certainty is still low. It supports working capital and RTO costs, but it is not growth capital and does not validate valuation. ATM facilities improve short-term solvency, not long-term equity value, and introduce ongoing supply by design. That’s normal ahead of a high-uncertainty event like an RTO. Upside still depends on the prospectus, funding terms and asset de-risking. This RNS doesn’t change those economics — it just extends the runway.

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: The RNS shows an ATM facility + warrant/loan conversion, which is standard bridge financing when optionality is high but certainty is still low. It supports working capital and RTO costs, but it is not growth capital and does not validate valuation. ATM facilities improve short-term solvency, not long-term equity value, and introduce ongoing supply by design. That’s normal ahead of a high-uncertainty event like an RTO. Upside still depends on the prospectus, funding terms and asset de-risking. This RNS doesn’t change those economics — it just extends the runway.

data.content: PEEL is the broker, book runner,  liquidity provider,  and market maker. There's an RTO event coming. Whilst PEEL is carrying their duties in the above roles, their holdings are changeable,  therefore they have released an RNS as below  10% range. If PEEL were looking to exit , they would not position themselves as prime buyer currently. If you were to sell shares right now it would be PEEL  taking them, if you were to buy shares right now it would be a different market maker giving them.

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: Amadan filling the vacuum with speculation to stay relevant on the BB. Is there much to read into the director appointment on its own? Yes, directors can be appointed ahead of strategic events, but AMG already has a clearly signposted one in progress — the proposed UPSA acquisition, drilling programme and CPR upgrade have all been explicitly flagged in RNS, with timelines into early 2026. You don’t really need to infer anything extra from a routine board change when the company itself has already laid out the roadmap. On the “director for hire” point, having multiple appointments is pretty common on AIM, particularly for NEDs brought in for governance, compliance or transaction experience. Unless there’s disclosure of equity incentives, warrants or deal-linked remuneration (which would normally require an RNS), it’s hard to conclude much beyond standard housekeeping. If anything, adding another director while progressing a potentially transformational acquisition is fairly normal — especially with a CPR, off-take discussions and possible re-admission considerations ahead. The material questions remain the same as before: •	quality of the upgraded CPR (measured vs inferred), •	conversion of LOIs into binding off-take, •	and the final structure/dilution of the UPSA transaction. The director appointment feels like background noise compared to those.

data.author: SmoothOperater
data.content: PMB 58 isn’t AMG-specific news. It just marks when the FCA can approve PRM prospectuses. That’s a procedural unlock, not a price claim or inside info.
data.thread_title: RE: New FCA rules from Monday

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: In related regulatory news, the London Stock Exchange and FCA have been concerned with misleading bulletin board commentary and potential market abuse. The FCA stresses that false or misleading statements online can breach Market Abuse Regulation (MAR) — positive or negative. That context matters: If a poster uses general regulatory changes to imply specific insider knowledge, that could itself be viewed as misleading commentary under MAR. The inference that this FCA bulletin is a near-term catalyst for share price movement in AMG is not supported directly by the bulletin itself. AMG — as an AIM-listed company — will eventually operate under the new admissions/prospectus regime once POATRs takes effect 19 January 2026. But it is not a catalyst specific to AMG. It’s a general rule change for the market at large. PMB 58 does not announce: Specific regulatory approval for AMG operations or permits A timetable for any decision affecting AMG Inside information about upcoming FCA action on AMG. So there is no direct regulatory inflection point for AMG spelled out in PMB 58. The inference that this FCA bulletin is a near-term catalyst for share price movement in AMG is not supported directly by the bulletin itself. PMB 58 is procedural and structural, not company-specific. It doesn’t contain approved news about AMG or any impending regulatory event. It’s a framework shift affecting most UK listed issuers, not a targeted development. If AMG intends to raise money or issue new securities, the new rules might eventually be beneficial — but not as an immediate trigger. What PMB 58 does NOT mean for AMG-  It does not announce regulatory approval. It does not provide inside information. It is not a company-specific catalyst. Posters may be trying to imply that regulatory reform broadly makes raising capital easier and that this could increase speculative interest or confidence. But assigning that as a short-term share price catalyst for AMG is not supported by the document itself.

data.author: OAPK20
data.content: Be wary of classic bulletin-board shorthand aimed at traders, not fundamentals investors. Those who constantly seeking to reassure holders that recent selling is “smart” or “managed”, not distressed. Those who constantly frame price action as constructive accumulation, not distribution. Trying to anchor expectations to a near-term catalyst (“next week”). This is soft ramping, not blatant hype. The motivation is to frame current trading as bullish smart-money positioning ahead of a catalyst, thereby supporting sentiment and near-term price expectations. It’s not evidence, but it is a useful tell about how the stock is being talked up into the next trading window. There is deliberate phrasing to justify Short-term volatility, Broker stock movement, Holding through uncertainty. This is doing a lot of work psychologically, but crucially, no details are provided, which allows readers to fill in the blanks with optimism. That strongly suggests a trader already positioned, or looking to exit into strength, or trying to stabilise sentiment before a catalyst (real or hoped-for). The repeated broker / volume behaviour claim without - Rising volume without VWAP drifting down - Late-day strength (not fades) - Sellers disappearing on dips - No spike in free float via RNS - would suggest recycling. If instead you see - Volume spikes + price capping - PEEL persistently on the offer - Close-at-low prints - then it’s distribution, not recycling. Does the predicted “regulatory inflection point” outcome change project economics? Or does it just allow the story to continue? If the latter expect recycling again. Why “regulatory inflection” is BB gold. It sounds binary and asymmetric, excuses volatility, can’t easily be disproven short-term, and creates a time anchor (“next week”) This is speculation-driven, not information-driven phrasing. Be wary of position-protective posting, not malicious, but not neutral. Typical motivations are prevent weak hands selling into their exit, encourage “one more week” holding behaviour, and frame noise as opportunity. Which is classic pre-event BB psychology. Such comments appear plausible, but not provable. It is sentiment management, not insight.
